message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: State-of-the-Art and Future Research Challenges in UAV Swarms
Paper Abstract: Due to their potential to accomplish complicated missions more effectively, UAV swarms have attracted a lot of attention lately. UAV swarm offers enhanced intelligence, improved coordination, increased flexibility, survivability, and reconfigurability. It is a multi-disciplinary system that necessitates a tight integration of several sub-systems, including optimal trajectory planning, localization, task coordination, etc. This review covers the important aspects of UAV swarms including swarm formation control, communication, swarm path planning, autonomy, coordination, and security. It additionally explores recent technical advancements in UAV swarm algorithms that have made the development of complex UAV swarm systems possible. This paper also provides insight into ethical aspects and the use cases of UAV swarms in various military, civilian, and entertainment applications. This paper is concluded by highlighting the potential future directions and challenges of UAV swarm technology and the need for more research and development to exploit their potential fully. Overall, this paper presents a comprehensive review of UAV swarm technology, addressing its potential for revolutionizing many fields and supporting advancements in the future.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"Trajectory optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory_optimization"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Motor planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_planning"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMPL"},{"title":"Trajectory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory"},{"title":"Motion control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_control"},{"title":"Trajectoid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectoid"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of trajectory planning and motion planning:

## Motion Planning

Motion planning is the process of computing a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.(no content)Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video games, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.(no content)Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.

## Trajectory Planning and Optimization

Trajectory optimization is the process of designing a trajectory that minimizes (or maximizes) some measure of performance while satisfying a set of constraints. Generally speaking, trajectory optimization is a technique for computing an open-loop solution to an optimal control problem.(no content)There are a wide variety of applications for trajectory optimization, primarily in robotics: industry, manipulation, walking, path-planning, and aerospace.

## Kinodynamic Planning

Kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.(no content)Applications include path planning for cars and ground vehicles, trajectory planning for quadrotors and other unmanned aerial vehicles, planning for robotic arms, and footstep and trajectory planning for walking and running robots.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "UAV swarms unmanned aerial vehicle". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## What are UAV Swarms?

Swarm drones are drones especially designed to operate together as robotic swarms.(no content)Military swarms are capable of surveillance and attack missions.

## How They Operate

In swarm formations, UAVs would launch from a distant base station, then fly together to a destination and separate, or individual units could separate from the swarm sooner. They then could fly back together in formation, or fly back individually.(no content)Flying in a delta formation can allow for a longer flight time with the same amount of energy. This saves time and resources and reduces the potential need to stop in dangerous territories.

## Applications

Swarms of micro aerial vehicles have been already tested in tasks of autonomous surveillance, plume tracking, and reconnaissance in a compact phalanx.(no content)Numerous works on cooperative swarms of unmanned ground and aerial vehicles have been conducted with target applications of cooperative environment monitoring, simultaneous localization and mapping, convoy protection, and moving target localization and tracking.

## Real-World Use

On 6 January 2018, Russian forces thwarted a drone (UAV) swarm attack on the Khmeimim Air Base, the first of this kind in the history of warfare.

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_behaviour"},{"title":"Delta formation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delta_formation"},{"title":"Swarming (military) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarming_(Military)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Swarmalators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarmalators"},{"title":"Swarming (honey bee) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarming_(honey_bee)"},{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Networked swarming warfare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_swarming_warfare"},{"title":"Swarming motility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarming_motility"}]

I've completed a web search for "swarm formation control." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Swarm Formation Control

Swarm robotics is the study of how to design independent systems of robots without centralized control, where the emerging swarming behavior of robotic swarms is created through the interactions between individual robots and the environment.

## Key Principles

Robots do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task.(no content)Relatively simple individual rules can produce a large set of complex swarm behaviors, with a key component being communication between the members of the group that build a system of constant feedback.

## Applications

A drone swarm may undertake different flight formations to reduce overall energy consumption due to drag forces.(no content)Delta formation is a flight pattern where multiple flying objects come together in a V in order to fly more efficiently, with each trailing object positioned slightly higher than the one in front to reduce wind resistance.

## Military and Advanced Applications

Swarming requires autonomous or semi-autonomous operating agents, with strong synchronization and communications among them, where senior commanders release resources to the swarm, but do not control them once released.(no content)Current systems can control teams of hundreds of micro aerial vehicles using GNSS systems like GPS, and swarms of micro aerial vehicles have been tested in tasks of autonomous surveillance, plume tracking, and reconnaissance in a compact phalanx.

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Simultaneous localization and mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_localization_and_mapping"},{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Monte Carlo localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_localization"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Gregory Dudek - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregory_Dudek"},{"title":"Human–robot interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction"},{"title":"Neurorobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurorobotics"},{"title":"Wolfram Burgard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolfram_Burgard"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of localization in robotics:

## Definition

Robot localization denotes the robot's ability to establish its own position and orientation within the frame of reference.

## Key Concepts

**Sensing Methods:** Localization is calculated by one or more means, using sensors such as motor encoders, vision, Stereopsis, lasers and global positioning systems.

**Challenges:** Robots use two main sources of information for localization:
- Dead reckoning methods such as tracking the number of revolutions of its wheels can give the absolute position of the robot, but is subject to cumulative error, which can grow quickly.
- The allothetic source corresponds to the sensors of the robot, like a camera, a microphone, laser, lidar, or sonar.

## Related Techniques

**SLAM:** Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

**Monte Carlo Localization:** Monte Carlo localization (MCL), also known as particle filter localization, is an algorithm for robots to localize using a particle filter. Given a map of the environment, the algorithm estimates the position and orientation of a robot as it moves and senses the environment.

Localization is fundamental to autonomous robot navigation and enables robots to perform tasks like path planning, mapping, and obstacle avoidance in their environments.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of localization in robotics:

## Definition

Robot localization denotes the robot's ability to establish its own position and orientation within the frame of reference.

## Key Concepts

**Sensing Methods:** Localization is calculated by one or more means, using sensors such as motor encoders, vision, Stereopsis, lasers and global positioning systems.

**Challenges:** Robots use two main sources of information for localization:
- Dead reckoning methods such as tracking the number of revolutions of its wheels can give the absolute position of the robot, but is subject to cumulative error, which can grow quickly.
- The allothetic source corresponds to the sensors of the robot, like a camera, a microphone, laser, lidar, or sonar.

## Related Techniques

**SLAM:** Simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) is the computational problem of constructing or updating a map of an unknown environment while simultaneously keeping track of an agent's location within it.

**Monte Carlo Localization:** Monte Carlo localization (MCL), also known as particle filter localization, is an algorithm for robots to localize using a particle filter. Given a map of the environment, the algorithm estimates the position and orientation of a robot as it moves and senses the environment.

Localization is fundamental to autonomous robot navigation and enables robots to perform tasks like path planning, mapping, and obstacle avoidance in their environments.

Links: [{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"D* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D*"},{"title":"Rapidly exploring random tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapidly_exploring_random_tree"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Vector Field Histogram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_Field_Histogram"},{"title":"Graphical path method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphical_path_method"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about path planning algorithms:

## Overview

Motion planning, also called path planning, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Types of Path Planning

Path planning algorithms can be categorized in several ways:

**Global vs. Local Planning:**
- Global path planning refers to methods that require prior knowledge of the robot's environment.
- Local path planning refers to methods that take in information from the surroundings in order to generate a simulated field where a path can be found. This allows a path to be found in the real-time as well as adapt to dynamic obstacles.

## Major Algorithm Categories

**Probabilistic Roadmap (PRM):**
The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

**Rapidly Exploring Random Trees (RRT):**
A rapidly exploring random tree (RRT) is an algorithm designed to efficiently search nonconvex, high-dimensional spaces by randomly building a space-filling tree. The tree is constructed incrementally from samples drawn randomly from the search space and is inherently biased to grow towards large unsearched areas of the problem.

**Any-Angle Path Planning:**
Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle. The result is a path that cuts directly through open areas and has relatively few turns.

**Vector Field Histogram (VFH):**
Vector Field Histogram (VFH) is a real time motion planning algorithm proposed by Johann Borenstein and Yoram Koren in 1991. The VFH utilizes a statistical representation of the robot's environment through the so-called histogram grid, and therefore places great emphasis on dealing with uncertainty from sensor and modeling errors.

## Applications

RRTs easily handle problems with obstacles and differential constraints (nonholonomic and kinodynamic) and have been widely used in autonomous robotic motion planning.

Based on the web search results, here's information about task coordination in multi-agent systems:

## Overview

Multi-agent planning involves coordinating the resources and activities of multiple agents.(no content)A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents that can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Coordination Mechanisms

Agent actions are typically mediated via an appropriate middleware that offers a first-class design abstraction for multi-agent systems, providing means to govern resource access and agent coordination.(no content)Task coordination can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans (plan merging) or planning of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.

## Communication and Coordination

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, example languages are Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Challenges

Issues with multi-agent systems include few coordination protocols between component agents, inconsistent performance, and challenges debugging. Additionally, as systems become more complex and more agents are used, maintaining coordination and avoiding conflicts becomes increasingly difficult.

## Applications

Multi-agent systems are applied in real-world applications including transportation, logistics, graphics, manufacturing, power systems, smartgrids, and GIS.

I've performed a web search on "communication networks distributed systems." Here are the key findings:

## Distributed Computing and Communication

Distributed computing is a field of computer science that studies distributed systems, defined as computer systems whose inter-communicating components are located on different networked computers. The components of a distributed system communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another in order to achieve a common goal.

## Architecture and Components

A typical distributed system is represented as a network topology in which each node is a computer and each line connecting the nodes is a communication link. Each computer has its own local memory, and information can be exchanged only by passing messages from one node to another by using the available communication links.

## Key Challenges

Three challenges of distributed systems are: maintaining concurrency of components, overcoming the lack of a global clock, and managing the independent failure of components.

## Types of Distributed Systems

Examples of distributed systems vary from SOA-based systems to microservices to massively multiplayer online games to peer-to-peer applications.

## Communication Methods

Peer-to-peer (P2P) computation is based on a decentralized, distributed network, including the distributed ledger technology such as blockchain.

Additionally, in a distributed computing environment, distributed object communication realizes communication between distributed objects. The main role is to allow objects to access data and invoke methods on remote objects (objects residing in non-local memory space).

I've performed a web search on "communication networks distributed systems." Here are the key findings:

## Distributed Computing and Communication

Distributed computing is a field of computer science that studies distributed systems, defined as computer systems whose inter-communicating components are located on different networked computers. The components of a distributed system communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another in order to achieve a common goal.

## Architecture and Components

A typical distributed system is represented as a network topology in which each node is a computer and each line connecting the nodes is a communication link. Each computer has its own local memory, and information can be exchanged only by passing messages from one node to another by using the available communication links.

## Key Challenges

Three challenges of distributed systems are: maintaining concurrency of components, overcoming the lack of a global clock, and managing the independent failure of components.

## Types of Distributed Systems

Examples of distributed systems vary from SOA-based systems to microservices to massively multiplayer online games to peer-to-peer applications.

## Communication Methods

Peer-to-peer (P2P) computation is based on a decentralized, distributed network, including the distributed ledger technology such as blockchain.

Additionally, in a distributed computing environment, distributed object communication realizes communication between distributed objects. The main role is to allow objects to access data and invoke methods on remote objects (objects residing in non-local memory space).

Links: [{"title":"Raytheon Intelligence, Information and Services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raytheon_Intelligence,_Information_and_Services"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned Systems Forces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_Systems_Forces"},{"title":"Camber Corporation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camber_Corporation"},{"title":"Singapore University of Technology and Design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singapore_University_of_Technology_and_Design"},{"title":"ELTA Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ELTA_Systems"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Unmanned Systems Forces (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_Systems_Forces_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"Unmanned systems of the British Army - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_systems_of_the_British_Army"},{"title":"Autonomous cargo ship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_cargo_ship"}]

The search results cover various aspects of unmanned systems and cybersecurity. Here's what I found:

## Overview of Cybersecurity and Unmanned Systems

Unmanned systems technology involves full life-cycle mission operations, engineering, sustainment and modernization services for site and platform missions. The field combines both cybersecurity and unmanned systems expertise across multiple sectors.

## Military and Defense Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), commonly known as drones, are aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather are controlled remotely or are autonomous. UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions too "dull, dirty or dangerous" for humans, and by the twenty-first, they had become essential assets to most militaries.

## Cybersecurity Challenges

Cyber security training for crew is another overlooked training that creates unstable safety environments, and presently, cyber security training for crew is not required. This is particularly relevant for autonomous and unmanned systems that depend on secure communications and control.

## Research and Development

Research on unmanned systems includes areas of defense system design and development, such as unmanned systems, information systems, soldier systems, and engineering systems. Additionally, cybersecurity and special missions units provide end-to-end cyber capabilities that address data and network security threats, including computer network defense, advanced persistent threat protection, and cyber hardening of military systems and critical infrastructure.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "autonomous systems robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"Institute of Robotics and Intelligent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_of_Robotics_and_Intelligent_Systems"},{"title":"Built Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Built_Robotics"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Robotic surgery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot-assisted_surgery"},{"title":"Lethal autonomous weapon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lethal_autonomous_weapon"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"}]

I've completed a web search for "autonomous systems robotics." Here's a summary of the results:

## Key Findings

**Definition and Overview**
Autonomous robots are robots which can perform desired tasks in unstructured environments without continuous human guidance.

**Applications**
The field encompasses diverse applications:
- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, while warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Built Robotics has created the "Exosystem," an aftermarket kit that adds autonomous robotic capabilities onto existing heavy equipment through GPS, cameras, and AI technology for autonomous excavation, earthmoving, and pile driving.
- Amazon launched its Astro for home monitoring, security and eldercare in September 2021.

**Navigation and Perception**
The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation. Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.

**Challenges**
Autonomous robots remain highly vulnerable to unexpected changes in real-world environments, as even minor variations like sudden sunlight or unanticipated terrain can cause systems to fail, stemming from robotics being an inherently systems problem.

message_text:
## Summary

I have successfully completed the analysis of the UAV Swarms paper. Here's what was accomplished:

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: **Survey** (not a contribution) - The paper is explicitly stated to be "a comprehensive review" of existing UAV swarm technology

### Extracted Triples (10 total)

The paper references the following key technologies and concepts:

1. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** - The core platforms forming swarms
2. **Swarm robotics** - Foundational principles for swarm design and operation
3. **Swarm behaviour** - Essential for understanding collective coordination
4. **Motion planning** - Critical for trajectory and path planning in swarms
5. **Robot navigation** - Enables UAVs to determine position and plan paths
6. **Simultaneous localization and mapping** - Allows autonomous mapping and navigation
7. **Distributed computing** - Underpins decentralized communication and coordination
8. **Multi-agent system** - Theory for task coordination and cooperation
9. **Autonomous robot** - Basis for independent UAV operation within swarms
10. **Swarm intelligence** - Principles for decentralized algorithms and collective decision-making

### Validation Result
✅ **All validation checks passed** - The triples_output.json file is properly formatted with:
- Correct paper type classification
- Valid Wikipedia URLs for all entities
- Proper entity types and relations
- Meaningful relevance statements
